electionName: 2026 Republican Primary â€” Large Ballot Test

candidates.name: John Smith
candidates.summary: Senior senator with 12 years of experience in federal legislation and committee leadership on armed services.
candidates.background: Former state attorney general who served two terms before winning his Senate seat. Graduate of UT Austin Law School. Previously worked as a federal prosecutor in the Southern District of Texas.
pros: Strong legislative track record with 47 bills passed
Deep committee experience on Armed Services and Judiciary
Secured $2.3B in border security funding
Bipartisan infrastructure deals for Texas highways
Consistent conservative voting record rated 94% by Heritage
cons: Voted against popular prescription drug pricing bill
Missed 12% of Senate votes in 2025 session
Accepted donations from pharmaceutical industry PACs
Slow to address rural broadband expansion
Criticized for insufficient disaster relief response

candidates.name: Maria Garcia
candidates.summary: Business executive and former city council member challenging from the right on immigration policy.
candidates.background: CEO of a mid-size manufacturing company in Houston. Served on Houston City Council for 8 years. MBA from Rice University. Active in Texas Republican Party since 2010.
pros: Successful business executive with job creation record
Strong grassroots fundraising at $4.2M raised
Fresh perspective from private sector experience
Endorsed by multiple conservative organizations
Clear policy positions on key voter issues
cons: No federal legislative experience
Limited foreign policy background
Some business dealings face scrutiny from media
Thin record on environmental policy positions
Narrow appeal beyond business community base

candidates.name: Robert Williams
candidates.summary: Retired military general bringing national security expertise to the race with strong veteran support.
candidates.background: Three-star general with 30 years of service including deployments to Iraq and Afghanistan. Commanded Joint Task Force operations. West Point graduate with masters from Naval War College.
pros: Extensive national security and military experience
Strong leadership credentials from 30-year career
Appeals to veteran and military family voters
No prior political baggage or controversial votes
cons: No elected office experience at any level
Limited understanding of domestic economic policy
Campaign organization still building infrastructure
Policy positions lack detail on healthcare and education

candidates.name: Sarah Johnson
candidates.summary: Current Attorney General seeking the governorship with a law-and-order platform and border security focus.
candidates.background: Served as Texas Attorney General for 6 years. Previously a district attorney in Tarrant County. Led multiple high-profile lawsuits against federal government overreach.
pros: Strong name recognition from AG office statewide
Proven track record of suing federal overreach
Deep donor network with $8.5M war chest
Clear ideological alignment with party base
Experience managing large state agency budget
cons: Several lawsuits faced scrutiny for political motivation
AG office had staff turnover issues under leadership
Limited economic development policy experience
Seen as too ideological by moderate suburban voters
Ethics complaints filed regarding campaign activities

candidates.name: Michael Brown
candidates.summary: Sitting lieutenant governor with deep legislative experience and a focus on education and property tax reform.
candidates.background: Lieutenant Governor for 4 years, previously served 12 years in the Texas Senate. Small business owner in Dallas. Known for shepherding property tax relief through the legislature.
pros: Deep legislative experience shepherding major bills
Broad coalition appeal across party factions
Strong record on property tax relief legislation
Known for bipartisan dealmaking when needed
cons: Perceived as moderate by some conservative activists
Grid reliability efforts drew criticism after 2021 storm
Some Senate votes opposed by party base members
Campaign fundraising trails primary opponent significantly

candidates.name: James Wilson
candidates.summary: Tech entrepreneur running on innovation, economic growth, and government modernization platform.
candidates.background: Founded two successful technology companies in Austin. Forbes 400 member. No prior political experience but active Republican donor and party event organizer.
pros: Self-funding campaign with $15M personal investment
Fresh outsider perspective on government efficiency
Strong appeal to younger and tech-sector voters
Impressive business track record creating 2000 jobs
cons: Zero political experience or government service record
Policy positions seen as too focused on tech sector
Limited appeal in rural Texas communities
Some business practices questioned by former employees

candidates.name: Patricia Davis
candidates.summary: State senator with 10 years experience leading on education and healthcare committee work.
candidates.background: Texas State Senator representing District 15 for 10 years. Former school superintendent. Led successful fights for teacher pay raises and rural hospital funding.
pros: Strong legislative record on education and healthcare
Deep relationships across the Texas Senate chamber
Proven fundraiser with $3.8M in contributions
Appeals to suburban women voters in key districts
cons: Some votes seen as too moderate on social issues
Limited name recognition outside her Senate district
Healthcare positions criticized by fiscal conservatives
No executive branch management experience

candidates.name: Thomas Anderson
candidates.summary: Former congressman bringing federal experience and national security credentials to the race.
candidates.background: Served 3 terms in U.S. Congress representing TX-22. Former Army officer. Lost reelection in 2024 redistricting. Active in conservative policy circles.
pros: Federal legislative experience provides broader perspective
Strong conservative credentials with Heritage 95% rating
Military service resonates with veteran voters statewide
National fundraising network from congressional campaigns
cons: Lost previous election which raises electability concerns
Federal focus may not translate to state-level priorities
Seen as a Washington insider by grassroots activists
Limited Texas state government experience and connections

candidates.name: Richard Martinez
candidates.summary: South Texas rancher and county judge running on rural issues and border community perspective.
candidates.background: County judge in Webb County for 8 years. Fourth-generation Texas rancher. Active in border community advocacy and agricultural policy.
pros: Authentic border community voice and perspective
Executive experience managing county government budget
Strong appeal to Hispanic Republican voters in South Texas
Practical knowledge of border and immigration issues
cons: Very limited statewide name recognition among voters
Small campaign budget compared to primary opponents
County-level experience may not prepare for statewide role
Some positions on border too nuanced for primary voters

candidates.name: Karen White
candidates.summary: Former federal prosecutor with expertise in cybercrime and public corruption cases.
candidates.background: 20 years as assistant U.S. Attorney in Northern District of Texas. Led cybercrime and public corruption units. Prosecuted over 200 federal cases with 95% conviction rate.

endorsements.name: Texas District and County Attorneys Association

pros: Extensive prosecutorial experience in federal courts
Non-political law enforcement career builds credibility
Expertise in emerging cybercrime threats is timely
Strong endorsements from law enforcement organizations
cons: No experience in civil litigation or state law practice
Campaign struggles to gain traction in crowded field
Perceived as too focused on federal-level issues
Limited grassroots organizing infrastructure statewide

candidates.name: David Lee
candidates.summary: State representative and constitutional law attorney with strong conservative legal credentials.
candidates.background: Texas State Rep for 6 years. Constitutional law attorney who argued cases before the Texas Supreme Court. Clerked for a Fifth Circuit judge after law school.
pros: Constitutional law expertise directly relevant to AG role
Legislative experience provides policy-making understanding
Strong conservative legal network and Federalist Society ties
Clear vision for using AG office to challenge federal overreach
cons: Limited management experience for large AG office staff
Some legal positions seen as too extreme for general election
Fundraising lags behind main opponent in primary race
State rep record includes some controversial floor votes

candidates.name: Lisa Chen
candidates.summary: Corporate attorney and former state solicitor general with appellate court experience.
candidates.background: Served as Texas Solicitor General for 4 years under previous AG. Partner at major Houston law firm specializing in appellate litigation.
pros: Direct AG office experience as former solicitor general
Strong appellate litigation skills from private practice
Business community support provides substantial fundraising
Brings management experience from large law firm partnership
cons: Perceived as establishment candidate by grassroots movement
Less visible conservative credentials than opponents
Corporate law background may not resonate with populist base
Limited criminal prosecution experience for AG role

candidates.name: Steven Taylor
candidates.summary: Incumbent comptroller seeking reelection on his record of fiscal transparency and technology modernization.
candidates.background: Comptroller for 4 years. Former CFO of a Fortune 500 company based in Dallas. CPA with 25 years of financial management experience.
pros: Strong incumbent advantage with proven track record
Modernized tax collection saving state $45M annually
Professional financial management background is relevant
Launched popular state spending transparency website
cons: Revenue projections were off by 8% last fiscal year
Office faced IT security breach affecting taxpayer data
Criticized for insufficient audit of state agency spending
Low profile means voters often skip this race

candidates.name: Nancy Parker
candidates.summary: State auditor challenging the incumbent on oversight and accountability track record.
candidates.background: State auditor for 6 years. Former Big Four accounting firm partner. Led major audits of state agencies that uncovered waste.
pros: Extensive auditing experience uncovering government waste
Specific plan to save $2B through audit recommendations
Strong taxpayer protection advocacy credentials
Independent reputation untainted by political dealmaking
cons: No executive management experience at comptroller scale
Audit recommendations often face political implementation barriers
Campaign lacks the fundraising of incumbent opponent
Narrow professional focus may limit broader policy vision

candidates.name: William Green
candidates.summary: Former state parks director with conservation and land management expertise seeking to lead the GLO.
candidates.background: Director of Texas Parks and Wildlife for 6 years. Environmental engineer by training. Led expansion of state park system and coastal restoration programs.
pros: Direct land management experience is directly relevant
Environmental engineering background aids coastal protection
Bipartisan appeal through conservation track record
Veterans land board reform plan addresses real problems
cons: Conservation focus may conflict with energy industry interests
Limited experience with oil and gas lease management
Name recognition is low even among engaged Republican voters
Some positions seen as too environmentally focused for primary

candidates.name: Jennifer Adams
candidates.summary: Oil and gas attorney focusing on maximizing state land revenue and energy development.
candidates.background: Energy law attorney with 15 years of experience in oil and gas lease negotiation. Represents landowners and mineral rights holders.
keyPositions: Maximize oil and gas lease revenue

endorsements.name: Texas Land and Mineral Owners Association

pros: Deep energy industry expertise for lease management
Property rights focus resonates with rural Texas voters
Strong fundraising from energy sector supporters
Clear plan to increase state land revenue streams
cons: No government management or agency leadership experience
Too closely tied to oil and gas industry for some voters
Limited coastal protection and conservation credentials
Veterans affairs experience is thin for land board role

candidates.name: Charles Moore
candidates.summary: Incumbent commissioner with 8 years on the RRC focused on energy industry regulation and grid reliability.
candidates.background: Petroleum engineer with 20 years in the oil and gas industry before being elected. Serves on the Interstate Oil and Gas Compact Commission.

endorsements.name: Texas Independent Producers and Royalty Owners

pros: Deep industry expertise from 20-year engineering career
Incumbent with established relationships across the industry
Led pipeline safety improvements reducing incidents 30%
Pragmatic approach to environmental compliance requirements
cons: Seen as too cozy with the industry being regulated
Slow response to grid reliability issues during 2021 freeze
Campaign primarily funded by industry PAC contributions
Reform proposals lack ambition according to clean energy advocates

candidates.name: Angela Foster
candidates.summary: Environmental engineer and energy consultant pushing for commission modernization and transparency.
candidates.background: Environmental engineer with experience at both oil companies and environmental consulting firms. Advocates for RRC name change to reflect actual mission.
pros: Bridge-builder between energy industry and environmental concerns
Fresh perspective on an often overlooked state commission
Orphan well cleanup plan addresses real environmental hazard
Appeals to younger Republican voters interested in reform
cons: Environmental credentials may alienate oil and gas base voters
No prior elected office or government agency experience
Limited fundraising compared to industry-backed incumbent
Renewable energy positions seen as anti-oil by some primary voters

candidates.name: David Hernandez
candidates.summary: Petroleum landman and small business owner running on deregulation and property rights platform.
candidates.background: Independent petroleum landman for 15 years. Small business owner. Active in Republican Party precinct organizing. Ran for state house in 2024.
keyPositions: Property rights protection for mineral owners
pros: Grassroots campaign with genuine small business credentials
Strong property rights message resonates with rural voters
Previous campaign experience from state house race attempt
Deregulation platform aligns with Republican primary electorate
cons: Very limited campaign funding and organizational support
No engineering or technical background in energy regulation
Previous state house campaign was unsuccessful in primary
Policy positions lack nuance on complex regulatory issues

candidates.name: Barbara Mitchell
candidates.summary: Incumbent state senator known for education reform and rural healthcare advocacy in Central Texas.
candidates.background: State Senator for 8 years. Former school board president and rancher in Williamson County. Led rural healthcare preservation legislation.
pros: Strong incumbent advantage with high approval ratings
Effective legislator who passed 23 bills in last session
Deep district ties from decades of community involvement
Bipartisan coalition building achieves real policy results
cons: Some conservative activists criticize moderate approach
Property tax reform efforts seen as insufficient by voters
Age concerns raised by opponent in campaign advertising
Limited social media and digital campaign presence

candidates.name: Kevin Price
candidates.summary: Young attorney challenging the incumbent from the right on school choice and parental rights issues.
candidates.background: Attorney specializing in education law. School board member for 4 years. Active in Moms for Liberty chapter. Age 34.
keyPositions: Ban on DEI in public schools
pros: Energetic young candidate brings generational appeal
Education law expertise directly relevant to key issues
Strong social media presence drives grassroots engagement
Clear ideological contrast with moderate incumbent senator
cons: Very limited experience in government beyond school board
Narrow issue focus may not appeal to broader electorate
Fundraising significantly behind well-established incumbent
Seen as too ideological for pragmatic-minded district voters

candidates.name: Diana Ross-Miller
candidates.summary: Former city council member focusing on suburban growth management and transportation infrastructure.
candidates.background: City council member in Cedar Park for 6 years. Urban planner by profession. Led successful transportation bond passage.
pros: Local government experience in rapidly growing district
Transportation expertise addresses top voter concern
Strong community relationships from city council service
Moderate profile appeals to suburban swing district
cons: Some city council votes criticized by fiscal conservatives
Growth management positions worry property rights advocates
Limited experience with state-level legislative process
Campaign infrastructure is still being built from scratch

candidates.name: Mark Thompson
candidates.summary: Small business owner and Army veteran running on fiscal conservatism and veterans affairs.
candidates.background: Owns a chain of fitness centers in the Austin suburbs. Army veteran who served two tours in Afghanistan. Active in veteran support organizations.

endorsements.name: National Federation of Independent Business TX

pros: Military service record provides strong candidate narrative
Small business ownership gives economic credibility
Veterans affairs focus fills important policy gap
Conservative fiscal platform aligns with primary electorate
cons: No prior elected office experience at any level
Campaign relies heavily on personal connections not data
Policy positions sometimes lack specific implementation details
Some voters prefer candidate with government experience

candidates.name: Susan Clark
candidates.summary: Retired school principal running on education reform and community safety platform.
candidates.background: Retired school principal with 25 years in education. Active in neighborhood watch and community policing advocacy. Known locally for school turnaround success.
pros: Deep education expertise from 25-year career in schools
Community safety focus appeals to suburban family voters
School turnaround success demonstrates leadership ability
Well-known in local community from decades of service
cons: No business or economic policy background experience
Campaign fundraising is well behind other primary opponents
Retired status may raise energy and commitment questions
Education-only focus limits appeal on broader policy issues

candidates.name: Ronald Kim
candidates.summary: Incumbent state representative in his third term focused on economic development and tech sector growth.
candidates.background: State rep for 6 years. Former technology executive at Dell. MBA from Wharton. Chairs the House Technology & Innovation Committee.
pros: Three-term incumbent with strong legislative track record
Technology expertise positions district for economic growth
Strong committee chairmanship amplifies district influence
Bipartisan approach to economic development legislation
cons: Tech industry focus may not address all district needs
Some votes seen as too moderate by conservative activists
Relies heavily on business PAC funding for campaigns
District demographic shifts may challenge reelection effort

candidates.name: Amy Wallace
candidates.summary: Homeschool mom and conservative activist challenging the incumbent on parental rights and education policy.
candidates.background: Homeschool mother of five. Founded local conservative parents group. Active in Republican Women of Williamson County. First-time candidate.
keyPositions: Ban on gender ideology in schools
pros: Authentic grassroots candidate with passionate base support
Parental rights message taps into current cultural movement
Social media skills generate significant earned media coverage
Clear ideological contrast with moderate incumbent representative
cons: No professional experience in government or policy making
Very narrow issue focus limited to education and family topics
Campaign budget is tiny fraction of incumbent war chest
First-time candidate may struggle with district-wide operation

candidates.name: Judge Helen Park
candidates.summary: Incumbent appellate judge with 12 years on the bench known for thorough and well-reasoned opinions.
candidates.background: Appellate judge for 12 years. Former civil litigation partner at major Austin law firm. UT Austin Law graduate. Clerked for Texas Supreme Court.

endorsements.name: Texas Supreme Court Justice (ret.) Nathan Hecht

pros: Extensive judicial experience with strong opinion quality
Textualist philosophy aligns with conservative legal values
Bar association endorsement signals professional competence
Court modernization efforts improved case disposition times
cons: Some rulings criticized as too moderate by conservative groups
Long judicial tenure may indicate entrenchment over innovation
Limited public profile means most voters unfamiliar with record
Campaign effort is minimal relying mainly on ballot position

candidates.name: Rachel Foster
candidates.summary: Conservative constitutional attorney seeking to bring originalist judicial philosophy to the appellate bench.
candidates.background: Constitutional law attorney for 15 years. Argued cases before Texas Supreme Court and Fifth Circuit. Active in Federalist Society Texas chapter.
pros: Strong originalist credentials appeal to conservative base
Appellate litigation experience directly relevant to role
Federalist Society ties provide intellectual framework
Younger candidate brings generational perspective to bench
cons: No judicial experience sitting on any bench at any level
Ideological approach may concern those wanting impartial judges
Limited trial court experience compared to sitting judge
Campaign fundraising trails incumbent with established donors

candidates.name: Margaret Cooper
candidates.summary: Incumbent SBOE member focused on curriculum standards and textbook review processes.
candidates.background: SBOE member for 8 years. Former school district curriculum director. PhD in Education from Texas A&M. Authored multiple curriculum standards.
pros: Deep curriculum expertise from professional education career
Incumbent experience navigating complex SBOE politics
Led phonics initiative improving reading scores statewide
Bipartisan approach gets actual standards improvements adopted
cons: Some curriculum decisions criticized by both left and right
Long tenure may indicate complacency on controversial issues
Limited public engagement beyond education policy circles
Moderate positions frustrate activists wanting bolder changes

candidates.name: Pastor James Wright
candidates.summary: Pastor and former teacher challenging incumbent on parental rights and curriculum transparency.
candidates.background: Senior pastor of large church in Round Rock. Former high school history teacher for 10 years. Active in school board advocacy.
pros: Teaching experience gives classroom-level understanding
Strong church community provides built-in volunteer base
Curriculum transparency message resonates with parents
Clear contrast with incumbent on cultural education issues
cons: No administrative or policy-making experience in education
Positions seen as too focused on culture war by moderates
Church leadership may raise separation of church and state concerns
Limited understanding of SBOE procedural and legal framework

candidates.name: Dr. Linda Nguyen
candidates.summary: STEM professor advocating for science education standards and technology integration in curriculum.
candidates.background: Professor of Computer Science at Texas State University. Former public school math teacher. Serves on several education technology advisory boards.
pros: Strong STEM credentials from university research career
Forward-looking technology education vision for Texas schools
Math and science teaching experience grounds policy in practice
Brings needed technical expertise to curriculum decisions
cons: Narrow STEM focus may not address broader curriculum needs
Academic background may seem disconnected from K-12 realities
Limited political experience and campaign infrastructure
Single-issue campaign may not sustain through full primary

candidates.name: Roger Fitzgerald
candidates.summary: Four-term congressman on the Ways and Means Committee focused on tax policy and trade.
candidates.background: U.S. Representative for 8 years. Former tax attorney and CPA. Serves on House Ways and Means Committee. Rice University and UT Law graduate.
pros: Ways and Means Committee seat gives outsized policy influence
Tax expertise directly relevant to key committee assignments
Strong constituent services operation rated highly by voters
Fundraising advantage with $2.8M cash on hand for reelection
cons: Voted for omnibus spending bill angering fiscal hawks
Free trade positions conflict with populist wing of party
Social Security reform stance worries senior citizen voters
Perceived as too focused on DC at expense of district needs

candidates.name: Ashley Ramirez
candidates.summary: Former Trump administration official challenging the incumbent on immigration and spending issues.
candidates.background: Served in DHS during Trump administration. Immigration policy advisor. Born and raised in the district. Georgetown Law graduate.
pros: Trump administration credentials provide strong brand
Immigration expertise is top issue for Republican primary voters
Fresh face offering generational change from longtime incumbent
National media attention generates free campaign publicity
cons: No legislative experience at any level of government
Single-issue immigration focus may limit general election appeal
Campaign organization thin compared to incumbent machine
Some Trump admin policies faced legal challenges and setbacks

candidates.name: Craig Patterson
candidates.summary: Two-term congressman focused on military affairs and veterans issues from Fort Hood district.
candidates.background: Former Army colonel with 26 years of service. U.S. Representative for 4 years. Serves on House Armed Services Committee.
pros: Military background directly serves Fort Cavazos district needs
Armed Services Committee seat protects local military installations
Veterans advocacy is authentic from personal service experience
Strong bipartisan credibility on defense and veterans issues
cons: Defense-heavy focus leaves domestic policy positions underdeveloped
Voted for bipartisan bills that angered conservative base members

candidates.name: Donna Mitchell
candidates.summary: Local business owner and school board member offering a civilian perspective on district needs beyond military.
candidates.background: Owner of regional accounting firm with 50 employees. School board member for 6 years. Active in Killeen Chamber of Commerce.
pros: Business ownership provides economic policy credibility

Offers needed civilian perspective in military-dominated district
cons: No military background in a heavily military-dependent district
Limited campaign funding compared to incumbent war chest

candidates.name: Tony Reeves
candidates.summary: Retired Marine and conservative activist pushing the incumbent from the right on cultural issues.
candidates.background: Retired Marine Master Sergeant. Conservative podcast host with 50,000 subscribers. Active in local Tea Party organization.
pros: Military background matches district demographics and culture
Social media following provides built-in campaign audience
Cultural conservative platform energizes grassroots primary voters
Authentic enlisted perspective differs from officer-class incumbent
cons: No governing experience beyond military service and activism
Polarizing cultural positions may alienate moderate district voters
Podcast career raises questions about legislative temperament

propositions.title: State Highway Fund Amendment
propositions.description: Dedicates a portion of oil and gas production tax revenue to the State Highway Fund for road maintenance.
propositions.background: Texas roads face a $15B maintenance backlog as population growth strains existing infrastructure.
propositions.fiscalImpact: Estimated $2.5B annually redirected from general revenue to highway fund.

propositions.title: Property Tax Homestead Exemption Increase
propositions.description: Increases the homestead exemption for school district property taxes from $100,000 to $150,000.
propositions.background: Rising property values have increased tax burdens despite previous exemption increases in 2023.
propositions.fiscalImpact: Estimated $1.8B reduction in school district property tax revenue, offset by state funding.
